utterances: (Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.

I'm Neal Conan in Washington, where earlier today President Bush promised his administration would rise above partisan differences after voters handed control of the House of Representatives, and maybe the U.S.
Senate, to the Democrats.
Speaking at the White House, he also said he's open to any idea or suggestion on Iraq.
And in Montana, incumbent Republican Senator Conrad Burns conceded defeat to Democrat John Tester.
Republican George Allen, trialing his Democratic opponent in Virginia, is expected to speak in about 40 minutes.
Today we're talking about this shift in American politics, what some call the end of an era where conservative ideas dominated the national agenda.
Did the Democrats win on Tuesday or did the Republicans lose?
Should Democrats work with the president where they can or oppose him at every turn?
E-mail, talk@npr.org.
Matt Bai writes on national politics for the New York Times magazine and is working on a book about the changes in the Democratic Party.
He joins us now from his office here in Washington.
Good to speak with you, Matt.
Hey, Neal.
Nice to talk to you again.
And I think you got a new chapter.
Well, I got too many chapters, but that's a different conversation.
Is this the end of an era?
You know, no, I don't think it is, and I'm going to take a slightly different tack from your last guest because I think this is an important point.
We kind of keep talking about this in terms of liberal versus conservative, or Democratic versus Republican.
We had a Republican wave, now that era's over.
We have a Democratic wave.
You know, the West was Republican, now it's going Democrat.
I would rather suggest to you that what we're seeing is the same continuum in American politics, and it's not best viewed as a conservative and liberal axis.
It's best viewed as an anti-Washington versus governing conflict.

And that's essentially what voters have been saying this country increasingly for decades - is that nothing is getting done to sort of turn us toward a 21st Century world, that nothing alleviates the economic insecurity and the insecurity they now have about foreign policy in the world, and that they don't believe that either party is addressing those concerns.
Good afternoon, Neal, and good afternoon, Peter.
And so what we have is the parties in power being turned out because they simply don't modernize or look forward.
They're still having - these two parties - the same fight they were having in 1975, and it means nothing to people.
So the wave of 1994 versus the wave of 2006 can be seen as two separate waves of two separate ideological tilts of the country.
But I would suggest they're not.
I would suggest it's the same wave, and that in fact, as you were just talking about, you know - the West, say Colorado, used to be conservative - suddenly it's going liberal.
I would suggest to you that it used to be anti-government and now it's anti-government, and it just depends on who's governing.
The good news for Democrats is you won and the bad news is you won.
That's precisely right.
The bad news is people expect something of you.
And if you don't deliver it - which, you know, for reasons we can get into, I think structurally they can't - then you're bound to be in the same situation again.
Because what people are registering here is an exhaustion with 20th Century politics in 21st Century environment.
One of the things that we talked a lot about - I think the last time you were on the program - was the battle between two electoral campaign tactics, as the Democrats were talking about.

Rahm Emanuel, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, wanted to spend all the money possible to win individual races around the country - seeing this as a historic opportunity to get back control of the House of Representatives.

And then you had Howard Dean, the chairman of the party, who wanted to use the 50-state strategy to build up the party in places where it had virtually evaporated - Alaska, for example - and reestablish the Democrats as a national party.
Did they both win?
Yeah.
I mean, think it's very hard to partiside(ph).

It's very hard to say well, this guy was right or that guy was right, and I think, you know, it was hard - I wrote about this in a cover story several weeks ago - and it was hard to come down on one side or the other then, and I think it is - I don't think the election made that any clearer.

I mean, certainly, Rahm Emanuel deserves most of the credit, I would think, of everyone you can talk about in this campaign because the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee did a fantastic job of recruiting candidates - the right kind of candidates - and a very good job of targeting races.

But it's also true - I think Governor Dean can claim some success in that a lot of the states where he has spent money on his 50-state strategy, they had a very strong turnout and a very strong - you know, and a very strong activist involvement.
Which, you know, he certainly can reasonably claim to have fueled that.

But I think in both cases - I will put it this way - in both cases I think neither of them are the winners they'll claim to be because the real driver here was Republican government and voter fatigue and exhaustion with the style as much as the substance of Republican government in Washington.

And I think that it was a great year if you were a leader of the Democratic Campaign Committee or the Democratic Party to look awfully smart as a result of what your opponents were doing rather than what you were doing.
Mm hmm.
Here's a phone call - Cheryl(ph).
Cheryl's joins us from Portsmouth, New Hampshire.
I agree on so many levels with what the gentleman before me just said.
I'm a firm Republican.
I feel I'm very conservative in my views, but I did vote Democratic because I felt like Washington was just not listening.
I heard a statement from President Bush when he was questioned about retaining Secretary of State Donald Rumsfeld, where his answer was something (unintelligible).
You're breaking - the line is breaking up, Cheryl.
Let's try it again.
And he's Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, and he was until yesterday.
I'm sorry, one more time.
He's Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, but your line was breaking up.
Let's try it again.
Okay.
With Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld where he says, you know, it's my decision.
Basically, I'm the boss, I'm in charge and this is my decision and everybody else has to stick with it.
I'm the decider, is I think the quote everybody remembers from that.
Yeah, and it's not - he is a representative of the people.
That's why I voted for Bush (unintelligible).
He was (unintelligible).
He wasn't (unintelligible).
Cheryl, your line is just too difficult to hear and I'm afraid we're going to have to let you go.
But Matt Bai, I think everybody remembers voters like Cheryl in New Hampshire delivered a critical stake to George W.
Bush.
Yeah, see, now my clicking phone doesn't seem so bad, does it?
No, it doesn't.
You know what, this goes to the heart of what I was just saying.
I don't mean to be a one-note song on this, but I think that's exactly right.
And again, we have a policy and a political establishment that I really believe is thinking about politics in terms of - they're no longer entirely relevant.
And we as a media institution do this too.
So, you know, they won't think about people like Cheryl in Portsmouth as being a Republican voter.
She therefore becomes a base voter, right?
She's a Republican, she's part of the red team, and she's always going to vote red.
American voters just don't look at it that way anymore.
It's a very different world.
They're not party identified.
Independents are growing much faster than either of the two parties are.
You know, she may vote Republican four or five straight elections but that doesn't make her Republican.
It doesn't mean she's satisfied with the direction of government.

I think what, you know - people really want some vision that goes beyond euphemisms and rhetoric of how to fix some very intractable problems and serious challenges, and I don't think they consider themselves part of a team.
Matt Bai, thanks very much.
Any time, Neal.
Matt Bai writes on national politics for the New York Times Magazine, working now on a book about changes in the Democratic Party.
He joined us by phone from his office.
Now I'm really drilling down on this.
But it is known as CAR, Will, I'm just saying.
Let's go now to Peter Beinart, editor of The New Republic and author of The Good Fight: Why Liberals and Only Liberals Can Win the War on Terror and Make America Great Again.
He's with us by phone from his office in town here today.
Thanks very much for joining us.
My pleasure.
And what do you think?
Do you think this is a significant shift?
I think that Matt is right.
Sorry to be so monotonous, but this was a referendum on George W.
Bush and the Republican Congress.

In 2004, the Democrats tried to make the presidential election a referendum and Bush and Rove were successful in making it a choice and there were enough people who were unhappy with Bush who also had anxieties about Kerry that Bush was able to get reelected.
But this - but a midterm election much more than a presidential election really is a referendum, particularly when one party controls all of the institutions of government.

And so all of the Democrats really had to do, I think, was show up and make a few intelligent tactical decisions and the enormous frustration and anger towards the Republican Party, you know, kind of made the difference.
Mm hmm.
I wonder, here's an e-mail we got from Steven(ph) in Phoenix: I'm a lifelong Republican who voted Demo this time.
Not because I've become a liberal but because I think President Bush is incompetent and my senator, John Kyl, agreed with the president too much and the GOP is too arrogant.
But the Dems have the same problems than they have had for decades.
Their base is smaller than the GOP base.
It is harder for them to energize their base without alienating the center than it is for the GOP, and the GOP is the party of ideas, even if them - even if them rather, do turn out to be bad ideas.
The Dems have no new ideas at all except things like gay marriage, which I don't oppose, which doesn't excite me.
All their other ideas - protectionism, minimum wage, etc., are right out of the 1930s.
Well, I don't think it's quite fair to say these ideas are right out of the 1930s.
The Democrats - the idea the Democrats want to push forward - things like the minimum wage, making it easier to pay for college - these are good ideas.
But right now what the Democratic Party still doesn't have is a larger narrative within which to understand why these things are important.

What the Democratic Party still has to do, which Bill Clinton did in '92, is tell Americans a story about the world which explains what's happening in their own lives, explains the rising economic insecurity that many middleclass Americans are facing, and then give an explanation about how an act - a more active government - not a bloated government, but an active, effective government - can empower people and allow them to succeed in this often quite destabilizing new global economy.
That I think is the kind of updated challenge that the Democratic Party faces.
And that's not going to be easy because these things are normally hashed out in the course of a campaign to find a presidential candidate.
Well, but that's why these two years are very important.
The Democrats were very effective in 1991 and 1992 in laying the groundwork in Congress for Clinton's presidential campaign.
For instance, by picking fights on healthcare, which then Clinton made his theme.
What the Democrats have to do, it seems to me, in the next two years is have a very robust internal debate about what that story is.
But also put forward legislative initiatives that focus the public's attention on those things.
Not with the belief that they're going to pass but with the belief that they can start to enter the intellectual bloodstream and then the Democratic nominee can pick up on them.
So not with the belief that they're going to pass bills they know aren't going anywhere, that President Bush will veto and that they're not going to be able to override.
Yes, that's right.
I think one has to be realistic.
We hear all this talk about bipartisanship, and there may be some areas where there can genuinely be movement.
But not a lot tends to happen in the last couple of years of a presidency.
And the Democrats should not support legislation that they think is bad just so they can pass legislation.
Their big opportunity - I think the wind is at the Democrats' back because of the collapse of the conservative ascendancy that started with Ronald Reagan.

And the Democrats should be focusing on trying to set things up, tee things up, for their opportunity to make more gains in the Senate in 2008, which they very well may be able to do, and to take the White House and then to move.
Here's another e-mail.
This from John in Durango, Colorado.
The statement Nancy Pelosi made yesterday explains it all, he writes.
If the Democrats want to continue to win, I am speaker of the entire House.
This is where the Republicans went wrong, alienating and demonizing them.
They had already the majority, could win every vote if they wanted but they didn't have to rub it in.
If the Democrats are inclusive, giving everyone a chance to have input, they would make all the difference in the world.
Not allowing Democrats on conference committee, not allowing amendments from Democrats, not allowing their input.
Those are the things that the voters rejected.
Whichever party learns this lesson quicker will win in 2008.
Do you agree?
Well, I do think that procedurally, certainly the Democrats should try to be more open.
I think they should also be reformist.
Part of what the Republican Congress did was it really shut down avenues for open debate, which I think was very unhealthy and the American people did not like.
But one has to be realistic.
There are very big, remaining, profound ideological divisions between the Democrats and the Republicans.
Let's take this minimum wage.
Democrats want to raise the minimum wage.
Most Republicans will say - at least as of last week - sure raise the minimum wage but only if you repeal the estate tax.
Democrats by and large genuinely believe in the estate tax.
They believe that it's actually central to the preservative of American meritocracy that we do not have a kind of oligarchic, a cast of wealth that's passed on from generation to generation.
And so I don't think the Democrats should be expected to compromise on that just so they can get bipartisan support for raising the minimum wage.
